utterances: Good to be with you, thanks for having me.
What kind of work did your father do for Trump?
He had a small telecom company in the 1980s.
And keep in mind, we're talking about an incident that was roughly 35 years ago.
And this company since has been sold over 20 years ago.
But it was one of Mr. Trump's first projects in New York City at the time.

And my father would often recall over the years - and he's particularly brought up in the last 18 months as Mr. Trump has been running for president - you know, an incident when he had a very, very hard time getting paid, and ultimately didn't get paid his full amount that was owed.
And so the message that was sent along was that you could take him to court, but it would ultimately cost more to sue him and litigate it out over the years than to just, you know, walk away.
You said this was a six-figure job.
That is a lot in today's money, it was certainly a lot of 1980s money.
How much of an impact did that have on your father's economic livelihood?
Yeah.
And like I said, this is - this was, you know, a recollection from over 35 years ago, so unfortunately we don't necessarily still have the documentation.
You know, look, he was more fortunate than others.
Many small business owners who worked with Donald Trump ultimately regretted it.
And, you know, fortunately, you know, my dad's company went on to succeed.
But it was also a lesson learned not to do business with him and his organization again.
Why did you decide to make this public on Twitter during the debate?
Well, I think like many Americans, you know, I have very serious concerns about not just Donald Trump's temperament, but his experience and qualifications for the job.
And as an American and a voter, Hillary Clinton's attacks resonated with me.
And I just was sitting there smiling saying yes, you know, I actually have a personal firsthand knowledge of this.
During the debate, Trump said maybe the work was shoddy, maybe I wasn't satisfied with it.
Could that be the case in your father's situation?
Well, my dad's recollection was that for months he and his organization made up every excuse they could think of to not have to pay their bills.
And they had to go back and he wanted this done over and this done over.
And then finally he ran out of excuses to pay the final invoice.
And he basically, you know, was told to take a hike.
The media has reported many stories similar to the one you're describing your father having experienced.
And yet, it's not at all clear that that is hurting Donald Trump in the polls.
Why do you think that is?
I think it's very surprising.
I think it's also surprising that it didn't come up more in the Republican primary.
But I think part of the issue is that there's so many Americans who just don't like Hillary Clinton, that they're willing to look past some of this.
Have you decided who you'll vote for?
I am firmly in none of the above.
I am a lifelong Republican.
And I couldn't bring myself - and there are - you know, there are some issues I support Hillary Clinton on like immigration reform.
But there are too many other issues that I couldn't bring myself to vote for her.
So I'm focused on hoping the Republicans control the House and the Senate.
And we'll see who wins in November.
But I will not be voting for either one of them.
Brian Walsh is a Republican strategist with a public affairs group Rokk Solutions.
The FBI director says that's what should happen.
I don't see it as--myself.
Women had rights before we invaded Iraq and women were recognized as equals before, especially women in the north.
The Kurdish women had strong Democratic rights.

And so, to take women and put them back--at the back of the bus so to speak and not give them full rights of citizenship and to subject Islamic law, which on divorce, on inheritance and many other issues would put women at the far back of the bus.
That would set women back even further.
So I support having a Democratic process or--I'm sure that many Iraqi women because I've seen a lot of their e-mails and their blogs, they want full democratic rights and not just partial rights.
All right.
One last topic before we go.
Republican Committee Chairman Ken Mehlman as you know has been out recruiting African-Americans.
And now Adam Hunter at Howard University has revived the Howard University College Republicans.
This is the first time in some time that Howard has had a college Republican group.
Donna, what do you think about this?
I mean, is it the case now that Ken Mehlman is making inroads into a younger generation this is going to negatively impact Democrats, negatively impact the power of the black vote among Democrats?
Well, let me applaud Ken Mehlman for the outreach that the RNC is doing now in trying to build a bridge across black America.
It's long overdue.
African-Americans are looking for leadership, leadership on many issues.
But more importantly, they are looking for both major political parties to address some systemic problems and issues.
So I think what you see here is young African-Americans open to listening to the Republican Party.
I don't know if this will translate into a mass movement to support conservative goals and philosophies.
Well, what numbers are you looking for here, Robert Traynham?
What kind of percentages is Ken Mehlman hoping to get out of young African-Americans going into the 2006 mid-term elections and then the 2008 presidential race?
Ken Mehlman sees exactly what everyone else sees, which is that the African-American community as a voting bloc is up for grabs.

African-Americans are traditionally conservative as it relates to stem cell, as it relates to Social Security, as it relates to faith-based--I mean, I can go down the list, marriage and the whole nine yards.
So having said that, what Ken Mehlman sees is a voting bloc that is really up for grabs.
All right.
Donna Brazile, former campaign manager for Democratic presidential nominee Al Gore in 2000 and the author of...
Cooking With Grease: Stirring the Pots in American Politics.
Cooking...
Now in paperback.
There you go.
And Robert Traynham, the GOP political strategist.
Thank you for joining us.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Join us every Thursday to hear more from Juan Williams and our Washington insiders right here on Political Corner.
You know, this is a year-end tradition as dependable as Christmas shopping and Hallmark Channel holiday movies - critics listing the best stuff they saw on television over the course of a year.
And at a time when there's over 400 scripted series on TV, this might be the most important list you are going to hear this month.
So let's bring in NPR TV critic Eric Deggans.
Hey, Eric.
Yeah, no pressure, dude (laughter).
No pressure.

Well, and I say this is important because I know it - I mean, the year is ending, but this is the time of year when, actually, like, after opening gifts or doing some cookie - you can actually sit and catch up on good TV.
That's what I always say.
This is sort of your binge-watching guide.
So I'll tell you a few things, and then you hop on the services and check them out, and that's your holiday season.
Done - consider it done.
All right, so what trends stuck out to you, and what should I be streaming in this holiday season?
Well, before we talk about specific shows - and I know this may sound like the understatement of the year - but 2017 really felt like the year of women in TV.
And it's not just for all of the sexual harassment scandals that have exposed so much of this awful behavior in Hollywood.

I predicted back in January that this year was going to be a real standout time for women because there's so many high-quality TV shows that have such great characters for women, that center on women, that are created by women, executive produced by women.
And...
Well, didn't we see some Golden Globe nominations that really speak to that recently?
Big Little Lies"" and ""The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel"" - I mean, they fit that bill, right?
Exactly.
I mean, ""Big Little Lies"" got the most nominations of any TV show in the Golden Globe Awards.
And they had four meaty parts for women in that show, and it was also executive produced by two of its stars.
So, you know, this is a time when we're seeing great roles for women, and it's reflected in a lot of the shows that I picked as my best this year.
Which are...
(Laughter).
What's your list?
Well, let's go to my top pick because I don't want to, you know, have people in suspense too much longer.
Good.
But my top pick is...
(SOUNDBITE OF DRUMROLL)
